File.Title: A Dopaminergic Projection to the Rat Mammillary Nuclei Demonstrated by Retrograde Transport of Wheat Germ Agglutinin-Horseradish Peroxidase and Tyrosine Hydroxylase Immunohistochemistry
File.Authors: A. GONZALO-RUIZ, A. ALONSO, J.M. SANZ, AND R.R. LLINAS

Abstract.S: The presence and distribution of dopaminergic neurons and terminals in the hypothalamus the rat were studied by tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) immunohistochemistry.
Strongly labelled TH-immunoreactive neurons were seen in the dorsomedial hypothalamic nucleus, periventricular region, zona incerta, arcuate nucleus, and supramammillary nucleus.
A few TH-positive neurons were also identified in the dorsal and ventral premammillary nucleus, as well as the lateral hypothalamic area.

TH-immunoreactive fibres and terminals were unevenly distributed in the mammillary nuclei; small, weakly labelled terminals were scattered in the medial mammillary nucleus, while large, strongly labelled, varicose terminals were densely concentrated in the internal part of the lateral mammillary nucleus.
A few dorsoventrally oriented TH-positive axon bundles were also identified in the lateral mammillary nucleus.

A dopaminergic projection to the mammillary nuclei from the supramammillary nucleus and lateral hypothalamic area was identified by double labelling with retrograde transport of wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase and TH-immunohistochemistry.
The lateral mammillary nucleus receives a weak dopaminergic projection from the medial, and stronger projections from the lateral, caudal supramammillary nucleus.
The double-labelled neurons in the lateral supramammillary nucleus appear to encapsulate the caudal end of the mammillary nuclei.
The medial mammillary nucleus receives a very light dopaminergic projection from the caudal lateral hypothalamic area.
These results suggest that the supramammillary nucleus is the principal source of the dopaminergic input to the mammillary nuclei, establishing a local TH-pathway in the mammillary complex.

The supramammillary cell groups are able to modulate the limbic system through its dopaminergic input to the mammillary nuclei as well as through its extensive dopaminergic projection to the lateral septal nucleus. 1992 Wiley-Liss, Inc.

Introduction.S: A number of reports have recently identified some of the neurotransmitters involved in the efferent and afferent connections of the mammillary complex (Storm-Mathisen and Opsahl, '78; Kiyama et al., '84, '86; Kovacs et al., '85; Fujii et d., '87; Shibata and Furukawa, '88).

The dopaminergic systems have been particularly examined in the rat hypothalamus by immunohistochemical localization of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH) (Bjorklund and Nobin, '73; Hokfelt et al., '76; Chan-Palay et al., '84; van den Pol et al., '84).

Since catecholamine containing neurons in the hypothalamus do not appear to be immunoreactive for the norepinephrine synthesizing enzyme dopamine-p-hydroxylase (Swanson and Hartman, '751, immunohistochemistry with TH can be used to study the dopamine systems of the hypothalamus.

In this region of the brain dopamine plays roles not only as a neurotransmitter (Bjorklund et al., '73; Hokfelt et al., '76; Kawano and Daikoku, '87) but also as a hormone in the hypothalamohypophysial axis (Tilders et al., '79; Barnes and Dyball, '82; Rack6 et al., '82).
Immunohistochemical studies (Chan-Palay et al., '84) have also shown that the mammillary nuclei contain a relatively high density of dopaminergic terminals.
However, little attention has been paid to the origins of the dopaminergic innervation of this complex.

In this study we have examined TH-positive afferent pathways to the mammillary body employing a combination of TH immunohistochemistry and retrograde transport of wheat germ agglutinin conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP).

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Experimental animals

Twenty-four albino rats (200-300 g) were divided into two groups, In one the localization and distribution of TH-immunoreactive neurons and terminals in the hypothalamus were determined with TH immunohistochemistry.
In the second group the localization and distribution of dopaminergic afferents to the mammillary nuclei were studied by combined retrograde transport of WGA-HRP and TH immunohistochemistry .
Immunohistochemistry for tyrosine h y dr oxyl as e

Seven rats were anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (dosage-45 mgikg) administered intraperitoneally and perfused through the heart with 50 ml of 0.9% saline, followed by 300 ml of a fixative solution consisting of 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.2).
The brains were quickly removed, blocked in the coronal plane, and immersed overnight at 4Â°C in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.2) containing 30% sucrose.
Forty microsections were cut through the hypothalamus with a freezing microtome.
They were collected in 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer and immediately processed for the immunohistochemical localization of TH by the avidinbiotin-complex (ABC) method of Hsu et al. ('81).
Briefly, free floating sections were immersed for 1 hour in 5% goat serum in phosphate buffered saline (PBS, 0.01 M) and incubated in highly diluted antibodies to TH (Eugene Tech.
Inc.; dilution 1:1,000) and 1% goat serum for 24 hours at 4"C, with constant agitation.
The characteristics and specificity of this antibody have been described (Fuxe et al., '78).
As a control, some sections were incubated in the same solution without the primary antibody.
After incubation, sections were washed in PBS and immersed in biotinylated anti-rabbit IgG (Vector; 1:200) in PBS for 1 hour at room temperature with constant agitation.

The sections were washed in PBS and immersed in an avidin biotinylated horseradish peroxidase complex (Vector; 1:lOO) for 1 hour at room temperature and washed through several changes of PBS and two changes of 0.1 M Tris-HC1 buffer (pH 7.6).
For the demonstration of peroxidase activity, the sections were immersed in 0.05% diaminobenzidine (DAB) and 0.01% hydrogen peroxide in 0.1 M Tris-HC1 buffer, pH 7.6, for 10-20 minutes.
This chromogen produced a diffuse brown reaction product.

Sections were rinsed through several changes of 0.1 M Tris-HC1 buffer, washed in 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer, mounted on gelatinized slides, dehydrated through ethanol to xylene, and coverslipped with Permount.
Surgical procedure.
The animals (17) were anesthetized with an intraperitoneal injection of sodium pentobarbital (dosage-45 mgikg) and placed in a stereotaxic frame.

A 10 pm glass micropipette (filled with 2% WGA-HRP dissolved in 0.1 M Tris-HC1 buffer, pH 7.9) was positioned stereotaxically into different regions of the mammillary nuclei (Paxinos and Watson, '86).
WGA-HRP (Sigma) was iontophoresed for 2-5 minutes with a constant current source providing positive current steps of 1.5-2 pA with a 7 seconds on and 7 seconds off cycle.
WGA-HRP histochemistry.

Twenty-four to 48 hours after the WGA-HRP injection, 11 rats (some of which were also used in the accompanying study: Gonzalo-Ruiz et al., '92) were transcardially perfused with 0.9% saline under deep anesthesia, followed by 300 ml of a fixative solution (1% paraformaldehyde and 1.25% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.2).
The brains were blocked and stored in sucroseibuffer overnight at 4Â°C.

Frozen coronal serial sections of the entire brain were cut at 40 pm, collected in 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer, and processed according to the procedure of Mesulam ('781, with tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) as the chromogen.
Following the reaction with hydrogen peroxide, the sections were washed in acetate buffer, placed on gelatinized slides, counterstained with neutral red, dehydrated, and mounted with Permount.
Sections were examined by light microscopy with brightand darkfield illumination.
WGA-HRPITH immunohistochemistry.
Each of the six rats used for the HRP-WGAITH-immunohistochemical double-labelling studies received an iontophoretic injection of 2% WGA-HRP dissolved in 0.1 M Tris-HC1 buffer (pH 7.9).

After a postinjection survival period of 24-48 hours, under deep sodium pentobarbital anesthesia, the animals were transcardially perfused with 50 ml of 0.9% saline, followed by 300 ml of fixative (2% paraformaldehyde, 0.1% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer containing 0.002% calcium chloride, pH 7.2).

Alternate sections first were processed for histochemical demonstration of retrogradely transported WGA-HRP by incubation for 10-15 minutes in 0.05% DAB tetrahydrochloride (Fluka) and 0.01% hydrogen peroxide containing 0.005% cobalt acetate and 0.005% nickel chloride in 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.2).
This chromogen produced a black granular reaction product.

After washing through several changes of 0.1 M sodium phosphate buffer over 4-18 hours, sections were processed for immunohistochemical localization of TH by the ABC method of Hsu et al. ('81) as described above.

Sections were examined and photographed by light microscopy with brightfield illumination and the location of single-labelled (immunoreactive-TH or retrograde WGAHRP) or double-labelled (TH and WGA-HRP) neurons was determined by reference to Paxinos and Watson ('86) and the descriptions of the tuberomammillary nucleus of Staines et al. ('87).

Results.S: RESULTS
Distribution of tyrosine hydroxylase
The distribution of TH-immunoreactive neurons in the hypothalamus of the rat was largely consistent with previous descriptions (Hokfelt et al., '76; Chan-Palay et al., '84).

Thus only a few points concerning TH immunoreactivity in the hypothalamus will be considered and attention will be focused on the mamrnillary nuclei , which have received comparatively little attention .

The location of TH - immunoreactive neuronal perikarya , identified on the basis of a diffuse brown staining of the soma and dendrites , is shown on the left side of the diagrams in Figure 1, and TH - labelled fibres and terminals are shown on the right side .
TH - immunoreactive neurons were found at the level of the periventricular region ( PV ) ( Fig . 1B - El .
Most of the TH - labelled neurons in the PV are fusiform with long axes located parallel to the wall of the third ventricle ( Fig . 2A ) .
Strongly TH - positive neurons appeared in the dorsomedial hypothalamic nucleus ; these cells are multipolar with three or four main dendrites .

TH - immunoreactive neurons also occupied the entire rostrocaudal extent of the zona incerta ( ZI ) ( Figs . lA , ZC ) , vith a particularly prominent cluster of labelled neurons extending from its medial part toward the midline near the periventricular gray ( Fig . 2C ) .
Most of the TH - positive neurons in the ZI are round to oval ; a few are triangular .
Most cells have two or three main dendrites showing a variety of arborization patterns (Fig. 2C).
Strongly TH - positive cells are also located in the arcuate nucleus ( Fig . lA , B ) ; these neurons are small and round or fusiform ( Fig . 2B ) .
The cells that are closest to the midline tend to have their long axis parallel to the ventricular wall.
A few TH - positive neurons , not described in previous studies , were seen below the arcuate nucleus , close to the surface of the hypothalamus ( Fig . 1A ) .
These cells are small and round to fusiform and their axons have a mediolateral orientation.
A few scattered TH - positive neurons were also seen in the dorsal and ventral premammillary nuclei and lateral hypothalamic area ( LH ) .
No TH - positive cells were found in the mammillary nuclei .
However , many labelled cells were seen in the supramammillary nucleus ( SUM ) ( Fig . 1B - F ) and in the adjacent ventral tegmental area ( VTA ) .
At rostral levels , large numbers of TH - positive neurons were seen in the medial part of the SUM , particularly along its ventral aspect ( Fig . 1B - D ) .
Most of these cells were small and round to fusiform ( Fig . 2E ) , though occasionally medium - size triangular cells were seen ( Fig . 2F ) .
At caudal levels , moderate numbers of TH - positive neurons were found in the SUM , appearing to encapsulate the caudal aspect of the mammillary nuclei ( Figs . 1E , F , 2D ) .
TH - positive fibres were distributed throughout the hypothalamus .
Many were characterized by the presence of small varicosities which probably represent terminals.
Long nonvaricose fibres were rarely observed .
These findings are summarized in Figure 1.
The SUM contained TH - positive terminals and dorsoventrally oriented axon bundles at all levels .
However , the TH - positive terminals were more numerous in the ventral than in the dorsal part of the nucleus ( Fig . 1B - E ) .
TH - immunoreactivity was inhomogeneously distributed in the medial mammillary nucleus ( MMN ) .
At rostral levels , dense TH - labelling , comprising axons and terminals , was found in the dorsal region of the pars medianus ( Mn ) and medialis ( MM ) of the MMN ( Figs . 1A - C , 3A ) .
In contrast , only weak TH - labelling was seen in the ventral part of the Mn and MM of the MMN ( Fig . 1A - C ) .
Further caudally , a moderate TH - labelling was seen in the ventral part of the Mn and MM of the MMN ( Fig . lD , E ) .
At more caudal levels , only small , scattered , and weakly labelled terminals were observed ( Figs . lF , 3B ) .
The pars lateralis ( ML ) of the MMN contained a moderate number of TH - positive terminals ( Fig . lC , D ) .

In fact , most of the TH - labelling was seen along the dorsal part of the ML of the MMN ( Figs . lC , D , 3 0 , whereas less strongly immunoreactive varicosities were seen throughout the ventral part of the ML .
A few strongly labelled fibres were followed from the ventral border of the SUM towards the dorsal aspect of the ML ( Fig . 3C , D ) .

The lateral mammillary nucleus ( LMN ) contained large numbers of TH - immunopositive varicose fibres and terminals ( Figs . 1C - E , 3E ) and a few dorsoventrally oriented axon bundles ( Fig . 3E ) .
The largest and most strongly labelled varicosities were densely packed in the internal part of the LMN at all rostrocaudal levels ( Fig . 1C - E ) .
Clear differences were observed in the density of TH - immunoreactive terminals in the LMN compared to the ML of the MMN ( Fig . 3E , F ) .

The axons of the more ventrally located TH - positive neurons in the lateral part of the SUM ( Fig . 4A , B ) bifurcated at the level of the capsule of the mammillary nuclei ( Fig . 4A , B ) and ran parallel to the capsule .
These axons then changed direction at an acute angle ( Fig . 4A , B ) , entered the LMN from its dorsal aspect , and distributed within the nucleus ( Fig . 4B ) .
Localization and extent of WGA - HRP injections

TTE.S: In the six experiments in which the mammillary nuclei were injected with WGA - HRP , the injections were positioned predominantly in the LMN at various rostrocaudal levels as shown in Figure 6A .
This area coincides with that showing a concentration of TH - immunopositive fibres and terminals ( Fig . 1C , D ) .
These injections produced moderate to dense retrograde labelling of neurons in the SUM .

Results.S: In one experiment in which the injection was confined primarily to the LMN , with slight spread into the MMN , a few retrogradely labelled neurons were also observed in the caudal region of the LH .
Distribution of retrograde WGA - HRP labelled and / or TH - immunoreactive neurons
In sections processed for the colocalization of TH and retrogradely transported WGA - HRP , the distribution of TH - immunoreactive neurons was similar to that described for Figures 1 and 5.
Neurons that were both TH - immunoreactive and retrogradely labelled with WGA - HRP were found throughout the SUM ( Fig . 5 ) .

These neurons were identified by the distribution throughout the soma and proximal dendrites of distinct black granules attributable to the retrograde transport of WGA - HRP superimposed on diffuse brown immunoreaction product ( Fig . 6C , F ) .
A few double - labelled neurons were found ipsilaterally in the medial part of the rostral SUM ( Fig . 5B - D ) , particularly in the area surrounding the mammillothalamic tract ( Fig . 6B ) .
At caudal levels , double - labelled neurons were found ipsilaterally in both the medial and the lateral part of the SUM ( Figs . 5D - F , 6E ) .
In addition , following an injection centered in the LMN , but extending into the MMN , a few double - labelled neurons were found in the caudal region of the ipsilateral LH ( Fig . 7B , C ) .
Double-labelled SUM and LH neurons could be distinguished from one another by their morphologies.
The double - labelled cells in the SUM were round to fusiform with two , or rarely three , processes ( Fig . 6C , F ) .
By contrast , the double - labelled neurons of the LH had triangular somata with three dendrites emerging from the soma ( Fig .
A few ( two or three cells per section ) retrogradely labelled cells that were not immunoreactive were scattered throughout the SUM ( Fig . 5B - F ) .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

Since our findings of the distribution of TH-positive neurons and terminals in the hypothalamus are similar to those reported in previous studies (Hokfelt et al., '76; Chan-Palay et al., '841, these will be covered only briefly.
Rather, we will concentrate on the dopaminergic projection to the mammillary nuclei, which has not received much attention in previous studies.
Distribution of dopaminergic cells and terminals in the hypothalamus

The distribution of TH-positive cells in the hypothalamus found in the present study (Fig. 1) was very similar to those in previous reports of studies using immunofluorescence techniques (Bjorklund and Nobin, '73; Hokfelt et al., '76; Fuxe et al., '78) or immunocytochemical methods (ChanPalay et al., '84; van den Pol et al., '84; Kawano and Daikoku, '87).
In agreement with previous studies (Swanson, '821, the present findings show that the supramammillary nucleus contains a large number of TH-positive neurons.

These dopaminergic cells (Skagerberg et al., '88) are particularly dense at rostral levels in the medial, smallcelled part of the supramammillary nucleus (Fig. 1) and in the lateral portion of the caudal pole lyingjust medial to the ventral tegmental area (Fig. 1).
At caudal levels the supramammillary nucleus can not be distinguished from the medial border of the ventral tegmental area by cytoarchitectonic criteria alone.
Thus, the TH-positive neurons in the supramammillary nucleus have been tentatively identified as a rostral, ventral extension of the A10 cell group (Swanson, '82; Hokfelt et al., '84).
The functional topography of TH-neurons in the supramamrnillary nucleus is considered below.

Although the distribution of TH-fibres and terminals in the hypothalamus was similar to that reported by ChanPalay et al. ('84), we have made some new observations regarding the TH-fibres and terminals in the mammillary nuclei.
Small, weakly labelled terminals were scattered in the medial mammillary nucleus and larger, more heavily labelled varicose terminals were concentrated in the lateral mammillary nucleus.

Axons from cell bodies in the supramammillary nucleus also collected ventrally and distributed into the dorsal part of the pars lateralis of the medial mammillary nucleus and into the lateral mammillary nucleus.
These data provide direct evidence that the mammillary nuclei receive a dopaminergic innervation from the supramammillary nucleus.

Some axons in the dorsoventrally oriented TH-positive axon bundles from the supramammillary nucleus that ramify profusely within the mammillary nuclei may also project to the tuberomammillary nucleus.

This THprojection to the tuberomammillary nucleus has not yet been established in the rat but a supramammillarytuberomammillary projection has been found in the monkey (Veazey et al., '82), while Jacobowitz and Palkovits ('74) have identified TH-immunoreactive terminals in the tuberomammillary nucleus.
A dopaminergic pathway from the supramammillary nucleus to the mammillary nuclei

Efferent projections have been described from the supramammillary nucleus of the rat to the nucleus accumbens, the lateral septum, the anterior limbic area, the entorhinal area (Carter and Fibiger, '771, the amygdala (Ottersen, '80), the hippocampus (Dilts and McGinty, '891, and the mammillary nuclei (Gonzalo-Ruiz et al., '92).
Swanson ('82) found that TH-positive neurons in the medial and lateral part of the supramammillary nucleus project massively to the lateral septal nucleus.

In the present study we employed WGA-HRP as a tracer in combination with TH immunohistochemistry to show that after injections of WGA-HRP into the lateral mammillary nucleus, double-labelled neurons were found 1) in the medial supramammillary nucleus and 2) in the dopamine region of the lateral portion of the caudal pole of the supramammillary nucleus.

These experiments suggest that the supramammillary nucleus contains TH-neurons axons with one axonal branch projecting to the septum and the other to the mammillary nuclei, but this possibility remains to be determined, although anatomical (Lindvall and Bjorklund, '74) and electrophysiological (Deniau et al., '80) studies have presented strong evidence that dopaminergic mesencephalic fibres bifurcate in the basal telencephalon to send branches to the septum and to the anterior limbic area.

The dopaminergic excitatory input to the mammillary nuclei and lateral septal nucleus may provide the morphological basis for the contribution of the supramammillary nucleus to the function of the limbic system, and perhaps this input should be considered as part of the "mesolimbic dopamine system."
Recently, it has been shown that dopaminergic cells in the supramammillary nucleus contain other hormonal peptides or neurotransmitters (Seroogy et al., '89).

The coexistence of dopamine and cholecystokinin (CCK), or histidine-isoleucine/vasoactive intestinal polypeptide or substance P within neurons of the rat supramammillary nucleus (Seroogy et al., '89), suggests that this nucleus is not chemically homogeneous.

Previous studies combining immunohistochemistry with lesions or retrograde tracing have reported CCK-positive projections from the supramammillary nucleus to the lateral septal nucleus (Seroogy and Fallon, '89), ventral tegmental nucleus of Gudden (Kiyama et al., '86), anterior thalamic nucleus (Kiyama et al., '84), and the hippocampus (Haglund et al., '84).

The dopaminergic neurons of the supramammillary nucleus have a substantial projection to the lateral septal nucleus (Swanson, ' 421, and some of the CCK-positive neurons of the supramammillary nucleus also project to the septal nuclei (Seroogy and Fallon, '89).
The demonstration of CCK/dopamine colocalization in the supramammillary nucleus (Seroogy et al., '88) supports the existence of a CCK/dopamine projection to the lateral septal nucleus.
In view of the present findings, it is possible that at least some of the TH-neurons of the supramammillary nucleus projecting to the mammillary nuclei also contain CCK.
Our data also raise the possibility that TH/CCK neurons in the supramammillary nucleus project to both the lateral septal and mammillary nuclei.
